title.narrative: Civil society capacity-building and UN advocacy: strengthening regional and international networks

description.narrative: The project focuses on mainstreaming the cross-cutting themes of development co-operation (climate change gender equality and reducing inequality) through strenghtening the regional and international civic society networks and better linking them with the UN Major Groups system. Economic and social inequality and marginalization hinder development worldwide. The detrimental effects of climate change fall upon the groups already in a vulnerable position such as the indigenous people. Marginalized groups such as disabled women in developing countries face multilpe discrimination.The project is based on consolidating the already existing regional networks in East Africa Central Asia and Caucasus and integrating these actors more effectively to the work of the U N Major Groups.The main methods of this initiative are advocacy work method workshops where regional actors can share their experiences and functioning practices deepen the know-how within their own sector and get support from experienced UN advocacy work professionals. The results of the workshop in 2015 will be produced as a book in 2016. The project includes a board game produced with facilitated teamwork. The board game familiarizes the importance of the cross-cutting themes and the challenges the group s in vulnerable position meet. After this the actors produce a power analysis of their own context and contemplate together the best possible methods for performing advocacy work. The material will include for example videos where different experts from di fferent UN sectors describe the significance of the cross-cutting themes climate change and equality and the rights of the groups in most vulnerable position in addition to thematic videos where the beneficiaries of the project share their own stories of c hange. The main beneficiaries of the project are the civic organizations in East Africa (Tanzania Kenya Ruanda Burundi and Uganda) Central Asia (Kazakhstan Tajikistan Uzbekistan and Kyrgyzia) Caucasus (Armenia Georgia and Azerbaijan) and indigenous people in project countries and elsewhere.
